--- Tyler Streeter <tylerstreeter@...> wrote:
> 
> > * joint angles
> > * forces on body parts
> >
> > Those are the things that an actual human being is
> > able to sense directly.
> 
> I've been thinking about this idea quite a bit-
> things
> we can sense directly and "senses" we deduce from
> our
> more direct senses.  Can we directly sense joint
> angles?  I'm guessing not.  I think we probably
> deduce
> that from our more direct "force" senses (i.e. sense
> of touch).  ...Not that that matters for this
> project.

It is well established that humans have a "kinesthetic
sense" which let's them "feel" the position of their
various body parts.  You can experience it.  Just
close your eyes and move your arms into different
positions, or better yet, relax them and have someone
else put them in different positions.  Can you feel
where your arms are?  (You should be able to.)

>  Of course, using simulated senses we ("real")
> humans
> don't have can help a simulated human.  However, I
> like the idea of making simulated humans mimic real
> humans as closely as possible since real humans seem
> to work pretty well.
> 
> I think there's a term for the sense of "knowing
> your
> limbs' positions, orientations, etc." is the
> "proprioceptive system."  So maybe an artificial
> neural network could build this sort of mental model
> given some primitive input.
> 
> Another sense could be the vestibular system (the
> circular tubes in our ears that help us sense
> angular
> velocities).  That would be pretty simple to
> implement
> and seems like it would help.

Certainly if you want your simulated human to balance
itself, you should simulate this.  I believe the
vestibular system senses angular acceleration and can
compute angular velocity from this information.
<snip>
